title: To what historical figures are the characters of Jidovi Mari of the Romanian folklore reminiscent of? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Jidovii Mari” (”The Great Jews”) are characters of Romanian folklore, and the legends about them can be found especially in the historical region of Muntenia.According to Romanian folklore, they were people of impressive height (a Great Jew would have measured as many as 25 ordinary people), who would have inhabited the land before ordinary people.In the old Romanian folklore there are several names for giants, one of them being that of "Jidovi Mari". In this way they then distinguished between “Evrei” (all the Jews of all times), “Jidovi” (that is, Jews of the Patriarchs), and “Israelites” (or, with a widespread popular form, “Jidani” - from the tribe of Judah, Judah, Jews, Jews). The difference is difficult to understand today, but for the Romanians of old it was clear: The “Great Jews” were the ones who “did God's will” and kept His way in Old Testament times, while others wandered. As a result, the name of ”Jidovi” was given to those giants who were considered good, wise, pure, and brave, as ”men of God”.

Q: “To what historical figures are the characters of Jidovi Mari of the Romanian folklore reminiscent of?” Oh, the Khazars again. The conversion of the Khazars resulted only in an elite religion with very little penetration, the Khazars where only the leaders of a coalition of various tribes including Alans/Ieşi and some Germanic communities which survived up to the Mongol invasion. The “Cumans” were a very heterogeneous coalition too. The Eastern European Jews are of a very well known origin: emigrants from the Rhine area which moved East during the Crusades, settled in Poland, then when most of Poland was taken over by the Russians moved around Russia. That the “Khazar” idea is still circulated is depressing. I have read about “Jidovi” being a mythical race of giants in Romanian folklore but I have not seen any folklore collected scientifically that mentions them. Yes, there is Densuşianu, he was the Pavel Coruţ of the late 1800s: for the Romanians that do not remember the ’90s or readers not introduced to Romanian pop-culture Nicolae Densuşianu was the steampunk equivalent of Erich von Däniken.
